text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.32.14, Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures, Gainsharing Travel Savings Program.
IRM 1.32.14.1.1(6), Background, updated section to specify Non-Bargaining Unit (NBU) employees must qualify to receive an award of at least $200 before taxes.

IRM 1.32.14.1.4(5), Program Management and Review, added if Travel Policy and Review determines the gainsharing awards paid are not accurate and compliant, a billing document may be established for repayment.
IRM 1.32.14.1.6, Deﬁnitions, added deﬁnition of Extended Temporary Duty (TDY) location.

IRM 1.32.14.2(4), General Rules, added maximum cumulative award of $10,000. A gainsharing award in the amount of $10,001 to $25,000 must be approved by the IRS Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support.
IRM 1.32.14.2(5), General Rules, added the award amount will be included in the employee’s Form W-2 , Wage and Tax Statement.
) IRM
)(a), General Rules, added no submissions for a gainsharing award will be accepted from employees after the deadline. Also, added IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. (
) IRM
)(b), General Rules, updated action for second-level manager. Also, added IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. (
) IRM
)(c), General Rules, added action for the business unit contact. Also, added IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. (
) IRM
)(d), General Rules, Added IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. (
) IRM
), General Rules, updated section for clariﬁcation. (
) IRM
), General Rules, updated requirements from NBU to all employees. Also, updated section to clarify eligibility requirements.
IRM 1.32.14.2(11), General Rules, updated requirements from NBU to all employees. Also, updated section to clarify eligibility requirements.

IRM 1.32.14.2(12), General Rules, added for NBU employees, only the ﬁrst 30 calendar days of extended TDY travel will count as eligible for savings in the program. For NBU employees, extended TDY of more than 30 calendar days where a reduced per diem amount is required is not eligible for gainsharing. For NBU employees, staying with family, friends or associates is not eligible after 30 days when an employee is on extended TDY travel.

IRM 1.32.14.2.2(4), Lodging Savings, added for NBU employees, only the ﬁrst 30 calendar days of extended TDY travel will count as eligible for savings in the program. For NBU employees, extended TDY of more than 30 calendar days where a reduced per diem amount is required is not eligible for gainsharing. For NBU employees, staying with family, friends or associates is not eligible after 30 days when an employee is on extended TDY travel.
IRM 1.32.14.4(1)(c), Travel Ineligible for Gainsharing, updated section for clariﬁcation.
IRM 1.32.14.4(1)(n), Travel Ineligible for Gainsharing, updated section for clariﬁcation.
1.32.14.4(1)(p), Travel Ineligible for Gainsharing, updated section for clariﬁcation.
1.32.14.5(1)(a), Gainsharing Award Process, updated section for clariﬁcation.
IRM 1.32.14.5(2)(c), Gainsharing Award Process, updated section for clariﬁcation.
IRM 1.32.14.5(3)(c), Gainsharing Award Process, updated action for second-level manager. Also, updated section for clariﬁcation.
1.32.14.5(4), Gainsharing Award Process, added action for business unit contact.
This revision includes changes throughout the document for the following:
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 1.32.14, dated March 31, 2020, is superseded. This IRM incorporated Interim Guidance Memorandum CFO-01-1220-0002, Interim Guidance for Non-Bargaining Unit (NBU) Employees for City-to-City Travel and the IRS Gainsharing Travel Saving Program, dated May 18, 2021.
AUDIENCE
All business units
Table of Contents
and (

) Purpose: This IRM provides policies and procedures for IRS employees who save the government money each ﬁscal year on common carrier transportation and lodging while on official city-to-city travel and who apply for a gainsharing award. (
) Audience: All business units (
) Policy Owner: CFO, Financial Management (
) Program Owner: CFO, Financial Management, Travel Management office, develops and maintains this IRM. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are IRS employees who perform city-to-city travel, including domestic and foreign travel, in the interest of the government. Additional stakeholders include the business units, ﬁrst- level managers, second-level managers, HCO and CFO. (

) Program Goals: To ensure that IRS employees exercise integrity while partici- pating in the gainsharing program and comply with the Federal Travel Regulation (FTR) and IRS policy when applying for a gainsharing award. (
) The Government Employees’ Incentive Awards Act (GEIAA),
USC
, authorizes an agency to pay a cash award for efficiency or economy. (
) In
, General Services Administration (GSA) provided guidance on a program known as “Gainsharing” where agencies could give cash awards to employees who participate in programs to save travel dollars. (
) Initiated and negotiated with NTEU by IRS on November
, the Gain- sharing Travel Savings Program is a voluntary program that rewards employees who save the IRS money on common carrier transportation and lodging while on official city-to-city travel. (

) At the core of the program are the principles that an employee must take mative, purposeful action to: a. Save public funds. b. Keep an accurate record of public funds saved. c. Provide documentation for review. (

) Based on these principles, the IRS has determined that the only savings it ognizes are those arising from an employee paying less than the maximum lodging rate for a Temporary Duty (TDY) location and/or using frequent traveler beneﬁts to purchase common carrier tickets for official travel. (
) The employee’s award amount will be
% of the savings on lodging expenses and/or contract carrier airfare when they qualify to receive an award of at $
before taxes for Bargaining Unit (BU) employees and at least $
before taxes for Non-Bargaining Unit (NBU) employees. (
) Federal, state, and local income taxes, and Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) taxes will be withheld on any award amount paid. (
) An employee can only submit one Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, that covers the entire ﬁscal year award period. Travel Savings Program
page
Gainsharing Travel Savings Program 1.32.14

Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are IRS employees who perform city-to-city travel, including domestic and foreign travel, in the interest of the government. Additional stakeholders include the business units, ﬁrst- level managers, second-level managers, HCO and CFO.
At the core of the program are the principles that an employee must take affir- mative, purposeful action to:
An employee can only submit one Form 13631-A, IRS Travel Savings, that covers the entire ﬁscal year award period.
1.32 Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
a. Tracking their gainsharing savings during the ﬁscal year. b. Preparing and submitting one completed Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form

for the immediately preceding ﬁscal year. c. Providing proof that the government travel card was used for payment. d. Providing proof of savings claimed for exchanging frequent traveler beneﬁts for a free common carrier ticket or lodging, such as the common carrier or lodging invoice. e. Providing proof of savings for lodging, such as the lodging invoice that displays the method of payment used. f. Adhering to all travel guidelines in IRM
, Official IRS City-to-City Travel Guide, in order to qualify for a gainsharing award. g. Paying any fees charged to participate in frequent travel programs with personal funds.

1.32 Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
a. Providing guidance on the IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program. b. Educating customers on travel policy, FTR, travel procedures and the gainsharing program. c. Authoring IRM

, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program, and travel guidance. d. Developing travel communications to educate travelers on the gainshar- ing program. e. Reviewing gainsharing requests for accuracy prior to ﬁnal approval. f. Reviewing the monthly gainsharing awards report and ensuring all awards were reviewed by Travel Policy and Review.
Internal controls are established to ensure the use of the IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program is managed effectively.
a.
% review of all vouchers and receipts related to the gainsharing award, Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gain- sharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, for accuracy and compliance with this IRM and the FTR. b.
% veriﬁcation of all gainsharing awards paid to ensure accuracy and compliance with this IRM and the FTR.
Gainsharing Travel Savings Program 1.32.14
If Travel Policy and Review determines the gainsharing awards paid are not accurate and compliant, a billing document may be established for repayment.
Several program controls are in place to ensure compliance with this IRM. They include, but are not limited to, the controls listed below:

City-to-city - A form of travel to a place, away from an employee’s official station, to which the employee is authorized to travel, which may involve an overnight stay or lodging expense. Common carrier - Airline, bus or rail transportation. Commuting area - The area within a
-mile radius of the employee’s residence and official station.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures

d. Contract city-pair fare - An airline transportation fare negotiated under contract by GSA. The fare is fully refundable and exchangeable and reserved for government travel. e. Extended Temporary Duty (TDY) Location - Employee is in TDY status for
consecutive days or longer at a single location, and the TDY location is farther than

miles from both the employee’s Post of Duty (POD) and residence. f. Frequent traveler beneﬁts - Miles or points accumulated using common carrier/hotel rewards programs that result in free common carrier tickets or hotel stays. g. Fe

ooms - A GSA program that provides hotels and motels that have agreed to provide lodging at rates equal to or less than the per diem rate for a given locality. h. Government travel card - A government contractor-issued card used pay for official IRS travel and allowable travel related expenses. Each travel card reﬂects an individual billed account established in the travel cardholder’s name. The term individually billed account (IBA) is synony- mous with travel card, credit card and government-issued travel card. i. Non-conventional Lodging - Any lodging that is not a traditional hotel/ motel type facility like Vacation Rental By Owner (VRBO), Air Bed and Breakfast (Ai

), long term apartment or condominium leasing. j. Temporary Duty (TDY) Location - A place, away from an employee’s official station, to which the employee is authorized to travel. k. Travel Management Center (TMC) - The travel agency operating under GSA contract that provides transportation, lodging and rental car services to the IRS.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures

(

) An employee may claim savings that are realized from staying in less expensive lodging and/or using frequent traveler beneﬁts to purchase common carrier tickets or lodging for official travel. All city-to-city travel outside of the commuting area with lodging expenses, foreign and domestic, are covered under this program. Relocation travel expenses are not eligible for this program. (
) IRS BU employees are eligible to participate in the gainsharing program when they qualify to receive an award of at least $
, before taxes. For example, BU employee who saves a combined total of $
in lodging and airline tickets during the ﬁscal year is eligible to share
% of the savings with the IRS. Total Savings = $

before taxes. For example, a NBU employee who saves a combined total of $
in lodging airline tickets during the ﬁscal year is eligible to share
% of the savings with the IRS. Total Savings = $

for a NBU employee. (
) The maximum cumulative award that can be paid without higher level approval for a ﬁscal year is $

must be approved by the IRS Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support. (
) Federal, state and local income taxes, and FICA tax will be withheld from the award. The award amount will be included in the employee’s Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statement. (
) An employee accumulates travel savings over a ﬁscal year period and documents the savings by utilizing Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings. (
) An employee must submit one Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, with supporting documentation, to the individual’s manager no later than December
for the immediately preceding ﬁscal year. No submissions for a gainsharing award be accepted from employees after the deadline. Savings Program
page Internal Revenue Manual
Gainsharing Travel Savings Program 1.32.14
An employee accumulates travel savings over a ﬁscal year period and documents the savings by utilizing Form 13631-A, IRS Travel Savings.
a. The ﬁrst-level manager reviews Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, with supporting documentation, submitted by the employee and approves or denies the request. b. If approved, the second-level manager reviews Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, and forwards this, with the supporting documentation, to the business unit contact no later than January
for the immediately preceding ﬁscal year. c. The business unit contact reviews Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, and submits the required forms and documentation to Travel Policy and Review no later than March
for the immediately preceding ﬁscal year. d. Travel Policy and Review reviews Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, submitted by the business unit contact and approves or denies the request, and forwards to the business unit contact within
days of receipt of all required forms and documentation. (
) Claims for ﬁscal year gainsharing awards must be paid by September
of the subsequent year. (
) An employee can only submit one request for a gainsharing award for a ﬁscal year. (
) A gainsharing award may be withheld if deemed necessary to protect IRS’s integrity. (

) Federal employees should always stay in a ﬁre-safe facility. Some non- conventional lodging facilities may not meet the ﬁre-safe requirements and should not be used. For an employee to use non-conventional lodging, an exception must be approved in advance by the Associate CFO for Financial Management and the approval must be uploaded into Electronic Travel System (ETS). Exception requests should be submitted in writing by the business unit head of office no later than

days prior to the start date of the travel and should detail the reasons why non-conventional lodging is needed and provide evidence that traditional hotels were not available. The request must also include documentation showing that the home-sharing rental meets the Hotel and Motel Fire Safety Act and Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) requirements. The list of approved hotels and motels for federal travelers can be found at: https://apps.usfa.fema.gov/hotel/ . The written request and all supporting documentation must be submitted to the *CFO-FM-Travel Policy & Review mailbox. Non-conventional lodging will not be approved for an employee’s convenience (e.g., family traveling with them). Non-conventional lodging such as leased or rented houses, apartments, condominiums or home- sharing rentals (i.e. Ai
, VRBO and Hom
way) not approved by the Asso- ciate CFO for Financial Management prior to travel is not eligible for gainsharing. (
) For NBU employees, only the ﬁrst
calendar days of extended TDY travel will count as eligible for savings in the program. For NBU employees, extended TDY of more than
calendar days where a reduced per diem amount is required is not eligible for gainsharing. For NBU employees, staying with family, friends or associates is not eligible after
days when an employee is on extended TDY travel.

days of receipt of all required forms and documentation. (
) Claims for ﬁscal year gainsharing awards must be paid by September
of the subsequent year. (
) An employee can only submit one request for a gainsharing award for a ﬁscal
) A centralized repository for all gainsharing records to include Forms
-A, IRS Travel Savings, Form

, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, and other supporting documentation must be established and main- tained. Gainsharing records must be kept in a centralized location for two years, following the GRS
Employee Management Records schedule. The GRS
schedule can be found at: http://www.archives.gov/records-mgmt/grs/. (
) Copies of approved travel authorizations and supporting documentation for manual vouchers must be maintained for six years in compliance with GRS
, item
Financial Transaction Records Related to Procuring Goods and Services, Paying Bills, Collecting Debts, and Accounting, records retention au- thorized disposition. The GRS
schedule can be found at: http://www. archives.gov/records-mgmt/grs/. (
) An employee who obtains a free airline ticket using frequent traveler beneﬁts earned on either official or personal travel is eligible for a gainsharing travel savings award. (

) Savings on airfare costs are measured by the contract city-pair fare in effect the time of the ﬂight, plus the applicable TMC fee. If there is no contract city- pair fare, the employee must use the lowest available non-restricted fully refundable coach class fare, plus applicable TMC fee, as the basis for deter- mining travel savings. (
) To determine savings, the employee must compare the city-pair fare with the cost of the actual airfare paid. (

) Acceptable documentation to support savings realized includes any of the following: a. TMC itinerary showing what the travel would have cost on a common carrier. b. A screen print from ETS showing the selected ﬂight information for the scheduled ﬂight. c. The ticketed invoice showing the frequent traveler beneﬁts redeemed trade-in value of the government airfare. d. A screen print of the city-pair fare for the contract carrier for both the origin and destination cities of the travel period. (

) An employee who incurs lodging expenses at a daily rate that is less than the maximum lodging locality rate may be eligible to receive a gainsharing award for lodging savings. Maximum lodging rates can be found at: www.gsa.gov/ portal/category/

) An employee may claim savings that are realized from using frequent traveler beneﬁts to purchase lodging for official travel. All city-to-city travel with lodging expenses, foreign and domestic, are covered under this program. Relocation travel expenses are not eligible for this program. (

) Eligible lodging savings must be the result of: a. Securing conventional or non-conventional lodging, resulting in zero or lower than GSA per diem rate for the TDY location. b. Sharing a room with another IRS traveler, where each traveler saves half of the single lodging rate every day. Each employee should request Travel Savings Program

Gainsharing Travel Savings Program 1.32.14

in value of the government airfare. A screen print of the city
pair fare for the contract carrier for both the origin and destination cities of the travel period.
origin and destination cities of the travel period. (

) An employee who incurs lodging expenses at a daily rate that is less than the maximum lodging locality rate may be eligible to receive a gainsharing award for lodging savings. Maximum lodging rates can be found at: www.gsa.gov/ portal/category/

) An employee may claim savings that are realized from using frequent traveler beneﬁts to purchase lodging for official travel. All city-to-city travel with lodging expenses, foreign and domestic, are covered under this program. Relocation travel expenses are not eligible for this program. (

) Eligible lodging savings must be the result of: a. Securing conventional or non-conventional lodging, resulting in zero or a lower than GSA per diem rate for the TDY location. b. Sharing a room with another IRS traveler, where each traveler saves one

a separate lodging receipt. However, if the employees are unable to obtain separate receipts, the employees need to determine the daily and divide the total lodging costs by the number of employees and the number of nights to arrive at a daily rate for each employee. c. Staying with family, friends or associates and incurring no lodging costs. Lodging costs must not be claimed on the travel voucher. (
) For NBU employees, only the ﬁrst
calendar days of extended TDY travel will count as eligible for savings in the program. For NBU employees, extended TDY of more than
calendar days where a reduced per diem amount is required is not eligible for gainsharing. For NBU employees, staying with family, friends or associates is not eligible after
days when an employee on extended TDY travel. (
) The employee must charge lodging expenses to a government travel card to be eligible for gainsharing, unless the vendor does not accept the credit card for payment. (

) If the lodging vendor does not accept a government travel card in payment lodging expenses, the employee may use personal funds. In order to be eligible for a gainsharing award when personal funds are used, an employee must provide a letter from the lodging vendor on company letterhead that clearly indicates the vendor does not accept the government travel card as payment for lodging expenses. (
) Employees should use tax-exempt certiﬁcates for lodging taxes, when appli- cable. Taxes on lodging are not considered in determining lodging savings. Transportation (
) An employee must take into consideration whether any additional transporta- tion or miscellaneous costs will be incurred when seeking lodging savings gainsharing eligibility. (

) An employee who incurs additional transportation expenses must deduct expenses from the lodging savings. Examples of excess transportation costs include, but are not limited to: a. Renting a vehicle for personal convenience at a TDY site to travel to from a place of free or reduced lodging. b. Driving a privately-owned vehicle (POV) more miles than would normally be traveled to or from the TDY site to obtain free or reduced lodging. c. Incurring excess taxi or mileage expenses or other public transportation fares that would not normally be incurred to obtain free or reduced lodging. (

) Examples include: a. An employee could stay at a hotel near the TDY location and incur no transportation expenses between the hotel and the TDY location. Instead, the employee chooses to stay farther away, at a less expensive hotel and, as a result, incurs extra transportation costs each way. The extra costs may be rental car fees, mileage, parking or the cost of public portation that would not have been incurred if the employee stayed at hotel near the TDY location. The excess costs of the transportation be deducted from the amount of the lodging savings.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
K (
1.32 Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
Employees should use tax-exempt certiﬁcates for lodging taxes, when appli- cable. Taxes on lodging are not considered in determining lodging savings.
Renting a vehicle for personal convenience at a TDY site to travel to and from a place of free or reduced lodging. Driving a privately

owned vehicle (POV) more miles than would normally be traveled to or from the TDY site to obtain free or reduced lodging. Incurring excess taxi or mileage expenses or other public transportation fares that would not normally be incurred to obtain free or reduced lodging.

a. An employee could stay at a hotel near the TDY location and incur no transportation expenses between the hotel and the TDY location. Instead, the employee chooses to stay farther away, at a less expensive hotel and, as a result, incurs extra transportation costs each way. The extra costs may be rental car fees, mileage, parking or the cost of public trans
portation that would not have been incurred if the employee stayed at a hotel near the TDY location. The excess costs of the transportation must be deducted from the amount of the lodging savings.
Gainsharing Travel Savings Program 1.32.14
b. An employee’s TDY location is New Carrollton, Maryland, for four nights. The lodging per diem rate per night is $

) The following activities are examples of travel ineligible for the Gainsharing Travel Savings Program: a. Relocation travel. b. Travel to an alternate location for personal reasons instead of staying at the TDY location. c. Lodging savings incurred due to an authorized or voluntary return to the employee’s residence or Post of Duty (POD). d. Travel paid by another government agency. e. Travel paid with personal credit card or funds, even if the employee has an approved exemption from the use of the travel card, except as provided in IRM

), Lodging Savings. f. Choosing an airport that has a lower city-pair contract rate or government rate does not qualify for travel savings. The only air travel savings that qualify are from using frequent traveler beneﬁts to purchase a coach class ticket. g. Departing a TDY early, arriving at a TDY late and/or choosing to forego an authorized rest period in order to save a night of lodging does not constitute lodging savings. h. Airport parking savings are not eligible for gainsharing. i. Using an alternate mode of transportation instead of the authorized mode of transportation to the TDY. j. Lodging that was prepaid, contracted or prearranged (e.g., block of rooms) through the IRS or the hotel, except if the savings resulted from shared ac- commodations with another IRS employee. k. Government Fe

ooms lodging, unless the accommodations are shared with another IRS employee on travel. l. Military base housing or military lodging, which are federally funded. m. Lodging costs incurred on annual leave or personal time used in conjunc- tion with official travel.

n. Domestic lodging that does not meet the requirements of the Hotel and Motel Fire Safety Act of

A list of lodging facilities that meet the re- quirements can be found at: Hotel and Motel Fire Safety . o. Non-conventional lodging such as leased or rented houses, apartments, condominiums or home-sharing rentals (i.e. Ai

, VRBO and Home- Away) not approved by the Associate CFO for Financial Management to travel is not eligible for gainsharing. p. Lodging expenses for staying at your personally owned or co-owned erty (e.g. vacation home, secondary home, rental units, timeshare, etc.), recreational vehicle or campers at the TDY location. q. While performing mission critical travel in the best interest of the govern- ment, if it becomes necessary to incur lodging at multiple locations for same travel dates, travel savings incurred at either TDY location is not gible for gainsharing. r. When traveling on an overnight or late-night ﬂight, lodging savings incurred during the ﬂight is ineligible for gainsharing. (
) The employee: a. Accumulates eligible travel savings incurred during a ﬁscal year and records the savings on one Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings. Only request may be submitted each ﬁscal year. b. Completes Form

, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. c. Signs and dates the forms supporting the qualifying savings. d. Submits the completed forms with reporting instructions, if applicable, travel vouchers and receipts to the ﬁrst-level manager. (

-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. b. Signs and dates the Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, as the recom- mending official. c. Submits the completed forms with reporting instructions, if applicable, travel vouchers and receipts to the second-level manager. (
) The second-level manager: a. Reviews the reporting instructions, if applicable, vouchers, receipts, recorded savings on Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. b. Approves by signing and dating Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, as the approving official. c. Forwards the completed forms with reporting instructions, if applicable, travel vouchers and receipts to the business unit contact. (

-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist. b. Forwards Form
-A, IRS Travel Savings, and Form
, IRS Gainsharing Travel Savings Program Checklist, to Travel Policy and Review at CFO.FM.Travel.Policy.Review@irs.gov.
